childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1976-1988

You were born the year America threw itself a 200th birthday party and tried not to think too hard about Vietnam. The Bicentennial was everywhere—red, white, and blue bunting on every porch, commemorative everything in every store, tall ships sailing into harbors while Gerald Ford smiled and nobody was quite sure why he was president.

Your childhood was the last gasp of analog simplicity. No internet. No cable in most homes until you were almost in middle school. Three networks, PBS, and whatever UHF channels came in fuzzy if you adjusted the rabbit ears just right. Saturday morning cartoons were a ritual. If you missed an episode, you waited for summer reruns or accepted you'd never see it.

You were four when Reagan was shot. Five when MTV launched and music became something you watched. Six when E.T. made everyone cry. Seven when Thriller turned Michael Jackson into something more than human. You grew up with Star Wars and Indiana Jones, with Atari and eventually Nintendo, with acid-washed jeans and big hair.

Your childhood straddled the Cold War's final act. You did duck-and-cover drills that nobody believed would help. You watched The Day After and understood, vaguely, that the world could end. Then the Berlin Wall fell when you were thirteen, and suddenly the existential threat you'd been raised to fear just... evaporated. You weren't sure what to replace it with.

Economically, your childhood was Reagan's America—morning in America, trickle-down economics, greed is good. Your parents probably benefited from the boom. You'd find out later that the prosperity was built on debt and deregulation that would eventually collapse. But in the moment, malls were cathedrals and consumerism was a religion.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Gen X, born between 1965 and 1980. The 'slacker' generation. The 'latchkey kids.' The generation sandwiched between the massive Boomer cohort and the even larger Millennials, perpetually overlooked and fine with it, honestly.

There are roughly 65 million of you in the US, which makes you the smallest living generation. You've spent your entire life being ignored by marketers obsessed with Boomers and now Millennials. This has its advantages. Nobody blames you for anything.

Your defining characteristic is skepticism. You watched your parents' idealism curdle into yuppie materialism. You saw Watergate expose the lies at the heart of government. You grew up during stagflation, oil crises, and hostage standoffs. Trust no one wasn't a TV show tagline—it was a survival strategy.

You're the divorce generation. More of you grew up in broken homes than any cohort before. You came home to empty houses, made your own dinners, figured things out alone. This made you self-reliant in ways that look like detachment to people who had more supervision.

Culturally, you were the first generation defined by irony and detachment. Earnestness was embarrassing. Everything was either stupid or a joke or both. You invented alternative rock, slacker comedies, and the pose of not caring even when you desperately did. The flannel was armor.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Rocky won Best Picture by punching the American Dream in the face. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest took home the previous year's Oscar. All the President's Men made journalism look heroic. Taxi Driver gave us 'You talkin' to me?' Network gave us 'I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it anymore.' 1976 was peak cynical '70s cinema.

Musically, you arrived during a strange transitional moment. Disco was ascending but not yet dominant. 'Bohemian Rhapsody' was on the charts. Boston, Fleetwood Mac, and Peter Frampton owned the airwaves. The Ramones and Sex Pistols were about to blow it all up with punk, but that hadn't quite landed yet.

Television in 1976 was Charlie's Angels, Laverne & Shirley, and Happy Days. The Bionic Woman debuted. Saturday Night Live was in its first full season, being dangerous in ways network TV hadn't seen. Mary Tyler Moore was ending its run, teaching America that a single woman could make it after all.

Your childhood belonged to Star Wars, which came out when you were one. The Empire Strikes Back when you were four. Return of the Jedi when you were seven. You don't remember a time before Star Wars. Neither does anyone else born after 1975. It rewired the culture.

By adolescence, you were deep in John Hughes territory. The Breakfast Club, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Sixteen Candles—these were your instruction manuals for surviving high school. MTV gave you the visual language: Duran Duran videos, Madonna's provocations, Michael Jackson's moonwalk. Music wasn't just sound anymore; it was spectacle.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Apple Computer was founded in a garage in Los Altos. Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak were building circuit boards while you were learning to crawl. The first Apple I sold for $666.66. The personal computer revolution was about to begin, and you'd grow up alongside it.

Your childhood was pre-digital but not pre-electronic. You had television, radio, cassette tapes, and eventually VCRs. The Sony Walkman came out when you were three, and suddenly music was portable. You could carry your own soundtrack everywhere.

You were nine when the first IBM PC launched. Twelve when the Macintosh arrived with its 'hello' and its mouse. You probably used computers in school—Apple IIs with green screens, typing classes that felt pointless, Oregon Trail killing your oxen. Computers were useful but not yet essential.

The internet arrived when you were in your late teens and early twenties. You remember dial-up, AOL Instant Messenger, the sound of a modem connecting. You were early adopters but not digital natives. You learned the internet; you didn't grow up inside it.

This gives you a particular perspective. You can function without constant connectivity because you remember life without it. You understand technology as a tool, not an environment. You're fluent in both analog and digital, comfortable with vinyl records and streaming services, paper maps and GPS. You're translators between worlds.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were four months old when Viking 1 landed on Mars and sent back the first photos from the surface. You don't remember it, but it was the culmination of everything the Space Age promised—humans reaching beyond Earth, even if only through machines.

You were four when Mount St. Helens exploded. Five when Reagan was shot, when AIDS was first identified, when the first space shuttle launched. You grew up in the shadow of the Cold War, with nuclear anxiety as background noise. Every crisis felt like it could be the last crisis.

You were ten when the Challenger exploded. You probably watched it live in a school classroom. The teacher was supposed to be first in space. Instead, you learned that progress has costs, that optimism can kill you, that adults don't always know what they're doing.

You were thirteen when the Berlin Wall fell. It was the end of everything your childhood had been built around—the binary of East vs. West, free vs. communist, us vs. them. The Cold War ended not with nuclear fire but with people chipping away at concrete with hammers.

You were fifteen during the Gulf War—the first televised war, CNN's coming-out party, a conflict that looked like a video game if you squinted. You were eighteen when the Soviet Union officially dissolved. The empire your parents had feared your whole childhood just stopped existing. What do you do with all that anxiety when the threat disappears?

You were nineteen when the World Trade Center was bombed the first time. Twenty-five during Columbine. Twenty-five during Y2K, which turned out to be nothing. Twenty-five when Bush v. Gore taught you that elections could be stolen in broad daylight.

You were twenty-five during 9/11. Old enough to be working, to be living independently, to understand exactly what was happening and what it meant. The before and after is cleaner for you than for younger people. You had decades of 'before.' The 'after' has been everything since.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the mid-to-late '90s, during the dot-com boom. If you were lucky, you got stock options that were worth something before they weren't. If you were unlucky, you got stock options that became toilet paper in 2000. Either way, you learned early that the economy is a casino.

Your generation pioneered the notion that jobs are temporary arrangements, not lifetime commitments. You watched your parents get laid off by companies they'd given decades to. You learned that loyalty is a one-way street, that 'family' in a corporate mission statement is a lie.

You're the generation that learned to job-hop before it was normalized. Not out of restlessness, but out of self-preservation. You climb by moving laterally. You negotiate by having options. You don't trust employers because employers gave you every reason not to.

You survived the dot-com crash in your mid-twenties. The 2008 financial crisis hit when you were thirty-two, hopefully with enough experience to weather it better than the kids just graduating. COVID hit when you were in your mid-forties, maybe managing people, maybe finally in a position of stability.

You've adapted more times than you can count. From typewriters to computers to smartphones. From office culture to remote work. From fax machines to email to Slack. You're not digital natives, but you're digital survivors. You learned every new system because the alternative was obsolescence.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the last generation that dated without apps. You met people in person—at bars, through friends, at work, in classes. You exchanged phone numbers on scraps of paper. You called people's houses and made small talk with their roommates or parents before getting to talk to them.

You experienced the full arc of communication technology. Landlines to cell phones to smartphones. Letters to email to text to DMs. You remember when long-distance calls cost money. You remember calling cards. You remember the anxiety of waiting by a phone that couldn't follow you.

Your generation married later than your parents but earlier than Millennials. Many of you divorced, because your generation normalized divorce in ways previous generations hadn't. You saw your parents' marriages fail and learned that staying together for the kids wasn't always the right call.

Friendships for Gen X tend to be smaller circles, deeper bonds, less performative than the social-media-driven connections that came later. You have friends you've known for decades. You don't need to broadcast the friendship to make it real.

You're comfortable with silence in ways younger generations aren't. You don't need constant contact to feel connected. A friend you haven't talked to in six months is still a friend. You pick up where you left off without needing to apologize for the gap.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You came of age during relative prosperity but learned early that prosperity is fragile. You watched the dot-com bubble inflate and pop. You watched the housing market do the same thing in 2008. You've seen enough cycles to know another crash is always coming.

Your financial advantages over Millennials are real but often overstated. Yes, college was cheaper when you went. Yes, houses were more affordable when you first bought. But you also got hit by the 2008 crisis in your early thirties, when you should have been accumulating wealth. Many of you lost houses, lost savings, lost years of financial progress.

You're the 401(k) generation, the first to fund your own retirements instead of relying on pensions. You watched the shift happen in real-time—companies eliminating defined benefits, pushing risk onto workers. You had to become amateur financial planners because nobody was going to plan for you.

Your relationship with money is pragmatic. You save because you've seen what happens when you don't. You invest because Social Security feels like a gamble. You don't trust institutions to protect you, so you protect yourself.

You're more financially secure than Millennials on average, but less secure than Boomers were at your age. You're the middle generation in every sense—caught between the prosperity your parents enjoyed and the precarity your children face.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest blind spot is mistaking cynicism for wisdom. You grew up distrustful, and that distrust has served you well in many ways. But somewhere along the line, skepticism calcified into reflexive dismissal. You reject earnestness because you've been burned by it, but earnestness isn't always naivete.

You're so used to being overlooked that you've made it a virtue. You pride yourself on not needing attention, but sometimes that means you don't advocate for yourself when you should. You let Boomers and Millennials dominate conversations you should be part of.

Your generation's ironic distance can read as apathy. You care, but you're uncomfortable showing it without a protective layer of sarcasm. This makes it hard for younger people to take you seriously as allies. They can't tell if you're with them or mocking them.

You adapted to so many broken systems that you sometimes forget the systems could be different. You're experts at survival within constraints, less expert at questioning whether the constraints should exist. You learned to work around problems instead of demanding they be fixed.

Your self-reliance can become isolation. You figured things out alone as latchkey kids, and you still default to handling everything yourself. Asking for help feels like weakness. But refusing help isn't strength—it's just stubbornness with better branding.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1996-2006): You graduated into the best economy in decades. The dot-com boom made everyone feel rich, even if they weren't. You probably had multiple jobs before turning thirty—not because you couldn't hold one, but because the economy rewarded movement. This was the decade of possibility. Things felt like they were going up and to the right. You were wrong, but you didn't know that yet.

Your 30s (2006-2016): The 2008 crash hit you in your early thirties. You were established enough to weather it better than younger workers, but it still hurt. Maybe you lost a house. Maybe you lost a job. Maybe you just watched your retirement accounts crater. This was supposed to be your building decade. Instead, it was your survival decade. You learned that no amount of doing things right protects you from systemic failure.

Your 40s (2016-2026): You're here now, or just past it. You're probably at peak earning potential, peak responsibility, peak exhaustion. Your kids, if you have them, might be teenagers or young adults. Your parents are aging, needing more from you. You're managing up and down, taking care of everyone, wondering when someone will take care of you. This is the decade where you either coast on what you've built or realize you need to change course.

Your 50s (2026-2036): This will be the decade of reckoning. Are you on track for retirement? (Probably not quite.) Are you healthy? (That becomes more pressing.) Do you still like your work? (Does it matter?) Your generation will age into a healthcare system that can't quite handle you. You'll watch your parents decline. You'll become the oldest generation in your family, which is a strange and unsettling transition.

Your 60s and beyond (2036+): Retirement is theoretical for most of Gen X. You'll probably work longer than your parents did, either by choice or necessity. Social Security will be there, maybe, probably reduced. Your savings will have to stretch further than you planned. The good news: you're adaptable. You've been adapting your whole life. One more adjustment is just Tuesday.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.2 million people born in 1976. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people in the US, making it the smallest living generation—squeezed between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're smaller, poorer, and less culturally dominant. Boomers got the postwar boom, affordable college, cheap housing, and cultural primacy. They've set the agenda your entire life. You've been following their lead, cleaning up their messes, waiting for them to step aside.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more financially stable but also more cynical. You had advantages they didn't—cheaper education, earlier entry into the housing market, less student debt. But you also had less support, less parental involvement, less cushioning. You raised yourselves. They were raised by helicopter parents.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're practically prehistoric. You grew up without the internet. They've never known a world without it. You remember privacy. They've never had it. You're confused by their optimism and their nihilism, often expressed simultaneously. They seem both more fragile and more resilient than you understand.

Your life expectancy is around 78-80 years, similar to Boomers but with more concern about the healthcare system's ability to support you. Your generation has elevated rates of 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdose, alcohol—though not as high as younger cohorts.

You're the forgotten middle child of generations. Not idealistic like Boomers. Not hopeful like Millennials once were. Not nihilistic like Gen Z. Just pragmatic, skeptical, self-reliant to a fault, and quietly waiting for the world to stop asking you to fix problems you didn't create.

year_events: Apple Computer founded in a garage
